required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Acute Effects of HIIT and SSMIT on Intraocular Pressure Among Sedentary Individuals
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Effects of High Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Steady State Moderate Intensity Training (SSMIT) on Intraocular Pressure Among Sedentary Individuals

brief_summary.textblock: Purpose to study the acute effects of both forms of aerobic exercise (HIIT and SSMIT) on intraocular pressure among healthy sedentary individuals

detailed_description.textblock:
40 participants were recruited and divided into 2 groups. Each group performed 2 exercise protocols with a 4 day washout period between them.
The intraocular pressure was measured before the exercise and after the exercise in 5 minute periods up until 30 minutes post exercise.
The intraocular pressure was measured using a handheld rebound tonometer.

primary_outcome.description: changes in intraocular pressure before and after exervcise

secondary_outcome.measure: compare which form of exercise (HIIT & SSMIT) is superior in reducing intraocular pressure
secondary_outcome.description: difference in intraocular pressure reduction observed between each exercise protocol

arm_group.description: undergo HIIT first then SSMIT protocol
undergo SSMIT first then HIIT protocol

intervention.description: aerobic exercise HIIT : High intensity interval training SSMIT : Steady state moderate intensity training

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- all University hospital staff
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous ocular trauma
- surgery in the eligible eye
- known case of glaucoma or glaucoma suspect (IOP > 21mmHg)
- history of glaucoma laser procedure/surgery within 6 months in eligible eye
- unable to undergo IOP measurements
- undiagnosed visual condition
- any uncontrolled medical condition such as end stage renal failure, uncontrolled diabetes and uncontrolled hypertension

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
